questions.text: A preterm neonate delivered one hour back in a PHC is rushed to the district hospital. There is an evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

  • Gastroschisis- The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
  • Omphalocele- The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia- This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Ectopia Vesicae/ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the lower abdominal wall does not form properly and the bladder is open and exposed.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: While performing the head-to-toe examination in a term 2.6kg neonate, a large, wide anterior fontanelle is noted. Which of the following congenital anomalies is least likely?
questions.solution:
In craniosynostosis, infants have small fontanelles. Craniosynostosis is the premature fusion of cranial sutures

An infant has 2 fontanelles at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle and the triangular posterior fontanelle.

  • Closure of the anterior fontanelle occurs at 18 months
  • Closure of the posterior fontanelle occurs by the 6th - 8th week after birth; its persistence suggests underlying hydrocephalus or congenital hypothyroidism.
  • The presence of a third fontanelle may suggest trisomy 21 or prematurity.

The persistence of excessively large anterior fontanelles and small fontanelles has been associated with several disorders:

Large fontanelles Small fontanelles

Achondroplasia

 Microcephaly
Cleidocranial dysostosis Craniosynostosis
Congenital rubella syndrome Congenital hyperthyroidism
Hydrocephaly Wormian bones
Osteogenesis imperfecta  
Prematurity  
Russell–Silver syndrome  
Trisomies 13, 18, and 21  
Vitamin D deficiency, rickets

questions.text: An anxious new mother brings her 18-day-old baby, to the casualty with complaints of poor feeding and yellowish discoloration of the skin. In the casualty, the baby had an episode of seizure. His total bilirubin is 32 mg/dl and he is diagnosed to have kernicterus. Which of the following will not be seen as a late feature of the disease?
questions.solution:
Hypotonia is seen in the early phase of kernicterus.

Kernicterus or bilirubin encephalopathy is a neurological syndrome resulting from the deposition of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei. It can result in permanent brain damage.

Early Phase (Acute)  Late Phase 
Poor suck Movement disorders - choreoathetosis, ballismus, tremor
Stupor Sensorineural hearing loss
Hypotonia  Defective upward gaze
Seizures

questions.text: What is the most common cause of seizures in a term neonate?
questions.solution:
Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is the most common cause of neonatal seizures in term babies. Seizures due to HIE typically appear within the first 12-24 hours of birth. Subtle seizures are the most common type of seizures in neonates with HIE. 

Neonatal seizures:

  • Most common type - Subtle seizures
  • Least common type - Myoclonic seizures
  • Most common metabolic cause - Hypoglycemia
  • Investigation of choice for the diagnosis of seizures - Electroencephalogram (EEG) 
  • Neuroimaging modality of choice for etiological evaluation - MRI
  • Drug of choice - Phenobarbitone

Most common cause of neonatal seizures in:

  • Term neonate - Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE)
  • Preterm neonate - Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The video clip of a 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs suggests a neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. 

A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. 

Other options: 

Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Option C: Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. They too cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedalling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies. 

Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. They can be provoked by stimulation.

Clinically apparent seizures in a neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures. In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before starting anti-epileptic drug treatment. 

Causes of neonatal seizure according to the age of presentation: 

1 to 4 days 4 to 14 days 2 to 8 weeks

Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy

Maternal use of narcotics or barbiturates

Drug toxicity: lidocaine, penicillin

Intraventricular hemorrhage

Hypocalcemia, sepsis, hypoglycemia, hypomagnesemia,  hypo or hypernatremia

Galactosemia, urea cycle disorders

Meningitis (bacterial)

Encephalitis (enteroviral, herpes simplex)

Hypocalcemia, hypoglycemia

Galactosemia, fructosemia, 

Hyperinsulinism, hyperammonemia syndrome

Herpes simplex or enteroviral encephalitis, bacterial meningitis

Subdural hematoma, child abuse

Aminoaciduria, urea cycle defects

Malformations of cortical development

Tuberous sclerosis

Sturge-Weber syndrome

questions.text:
A term neonate born to a lady with chorioamnionitis is diagnosed with neonatal sepsis. Which of the following statements are false?
  1. Infants with early-onset sepsis present with respiratory distress and pneumonia.
  2. Late-onset sepsis presents after 48 hours of life.
  3. Neutrophilia is the initial blood finding.
  4. All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a sepsis screen to corroborate the diagnosis.
  5. The presence of bacteremia is a must for diagnosis
questions.solution:
Late-onset sepsis usually presents after 72 hours of age (not 48 hours).

Neutropenia appears to be a better predictor of neonatal sepsis (not neutrophilia).

Neonatal sepsis is a clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of infection, with or without accompanying bacteremia in the first month of life.

  Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis
Presentation Within the first 72 hours of life After 72 hours of life
Source of infection Maternal genital tract Nosocomial or community-acquired
Manifestation Respiratory distress and pneumonia Septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis

Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella spp. are the predominant organisms involved. Organisms such as Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas, and coagulase-negative staphylococci are also important pathogens in hospital-acquired infections.

questions.text: Blood cultures drawn from a late preterm baby on day 8 of life show the growth of streptococcus species within 18 hours. An umbilical line tip culture also shows the same bacteria. Which among the following is the most common manifestation of the described type of neonatal sepsis?
questions.solution:
Bacterial growth in the umbilical tip and blood cultures on day 8 suggests a hospital-acquired infection after 72 hours. This is late-onset neonatal sepsis. 

The most common manifestation of late-onset neonatal sepsis is meningitis.

  Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis
Presentation Presents within first 72 hours of life Presents after 72 hours of life
Source of infection Maternal genital tract Nosocomial or community-acquired
Manifestation Respiratory distress and pneumonia Septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis

 

NOTE:

Traditionally, neonatal sepsis had been classified as EOS (<7 days) and LOS (>7days), but recently, experts have come to believe that Early-onset neonatal sepsis manifests within the first 72 hours of life and Late-onset neonatal sepsis after 72 hours of life.

questions.text: A focus of Klebsiella is detected in one of the ventilators during a routine quality and maintenance check in the NICU.  Sepsis protocol is enacted and a sepsis screen is ordered for all the neonates at risk.  Which of the following investigations is not sent as part of a neonatal sepsis screen?
questions.solution:
Absolute eosinophil count is not a component of neonatal sepsis screen.

The various components of the septic screen include:

  1. Total leukocyte count (TLC)
  2. Absolute neutrophil count (ANC)
  3. Immature: Total neutrophil ratio (IT),
  4. Micro-erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  5. C-reactive protein.

Blood culture: Gold standard for diagnosis.

All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a septic screen to corroborate the diagnosis.

Note:

Most common fungus causing neonatal sepsis: Candida species.

questions.text: Which of the following findings in a healthy term child would warrant further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Buphthalmos is not a normal finding in a newborn; it is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and should, therefore, be investigated.

The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos (“ox eye”).

Recommended screening for eye diseases at birth:

  • Buphthalmos
  • Cataract
  • Ophthalmia Neonatorum
  • Developmental anomalies - Microphthalmos, Anophthalmos
  • Nystagmus
  • Squint
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

questions.text: A neonate undergoing routine ophthalmological examination was found to have the finding shown below. Which among the following can be ruled out as the cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows leukokoria or white pupillary reflex. It is not seen in congenital glaucoma.

Leukokoria is seen in:

  • Congenital cataract 
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivers a 1.5 kg baby girl at 27 weeks of gestation. When is an ophthalmological examination recommended for the initial screening of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in this baby?

choices.text: At age equivalent to 32 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The first Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) screening in this baby should be conducted 2 weeks postnatal.

Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a vaso-proliferative disorder of the developing retinal blood vessels of the preterm infant, which may lead to poor visual acuity or blindness.

Criteria for screening:

  • Birth weight <2000g OR 
  • Gestational age <34 weeks OR
  • Gestational age between 34-36 weeks with the following risk factors - prolonged oxygen therapy (respiratory distress syndrome, apnea, cardiorespiratory support), neonatal sepsis, blood/exchange transfusion.

According to IAP guidelines, ROP screening should be conducted according to the table given below:

Period of gestation (POG) / birth weight Screening 
<28 weeks OR <1200g 2-3 weeks of postnatal age
>28 weeks OR >1200g 4 weeks of postnatal age

According to Nelson's 22nd edition, ROP screening should be conducted according to the table given below:

POG Screening
<28 weeks  31 weeks of POG
28-32 weeks  4 weeks of postnatal age

 

Annual follow-up is carried out unless indicated otherwise in cases where cryotherapy/laser treatment or cycloplegic refraction has been done.

This is a controversial question with different standard references stating different literature.

  • According to Nelson’s 22nd edition, the answer is 4 weeks postnatal in this case.
  • According to the latest IAP Standard Treatment Guidelines, the answer is 2 weeks postnatal in this case.

Hence, the answer depends on the reference used by the examiner. The answer in this particular MCQ is according to IAP guidelines.

questions.text: An infant born 48 hours back by vaginal delivery with birth asphyxia develops seizures. What stage of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the child likely to be in?
questions.solution:
Seizures are common in stage 2 of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).

Stages Seizures 
Stage 1 Nil 
Stage 2 Common 
Stage 3 Decerebration 

HIE is an important cause of permanent damage to CNS tissues, resulting in the following:

  • Neonatal Death
  • Cerebral Palsy
  • Developmental Delay

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida delivers a 3kg term baby after a cesarean section done in view of prolonged labor. The child cries 5 mins after birth and has a seizure 8 hours later. What is the imaging of choice for evaluation?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of prolonged labor, delayed cry after birth (birth asphyxia), and seizure suggest hypoxic-ischemic injury. The preferred imaging modality in term neonates with HIE is diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). This is because of its increased sensitivity and specificity early in the process and its ability to outline the topography of the lesion.

Computed Tomography (CT) is helpful in identifying focal hemorrhagic lesions, diffuse cortical injury, and damage to the basal ganglia, but limited ability during the first few days of life.

Ultrasonography (USG) - Neurosonogram is the initial preferred modality for preterm infants.  

Amplitude–integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) may help to determine which infants are at increased risk for long-term brain injury.    

Imaging modality in HIE:

  • Pre-term neonate - USG
  • Term neonate - MRI

questions.text: A 10-day old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is hyper-alert with mydriasis. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes and clonus. On investigations, a normal EEG is obtained. What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
Hyperactive tendon reflexes may be seen in stages 1 and 2; however, the infant is hyperalert with mydriasis and normal EEG findings in stage 1.

Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity

Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hour if progresses; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hour to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits

questions.text: A 1.4 Kg neonate is born at 29 weeks of gestation. The sonologist performing a neurosonogram is most likely to find an intracranial hemorrhage in the:
questions.solution:
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymal or germinal matrix.

In preterm infants, the germinal matrix (situated ventrolateral to lateral ventricles) is extensive and highly vascular which makes them prone to bleeding. Germinal matrix normally involutes during the third trimester.

Major neuropathologic lesions associated with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants are intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL).

Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is characterized by focal necrotic lesions in the periventricular white matter.

questions.text: A 2-week old infant with a birth weight of 1.8 Kg is being treated in the NICU for necrotizing enterocolitis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: Proximal part of the ileum is involved most frequently
It is associated with intestinal ischemia
It is more common in preterm infants

questions.solution:
The distal ileum and the proximal colon are involved most frequently in necrotizing enterocolitis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturity characterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterm infants, and prematurity is the biggest risk factor. 

The triad of intestinal ischemia (injury), enteral nutrition (metabolic substrate), and bacterial translocation have classically been linked to necrotizing enterocolitis.

Pathologic findings include necrotic segment(s) of intestine, gas accumulation in the submucosa of the bowel wall (pneumatosis intestinalis), and progression of the necrosis to perforation, peritonitis, sepsis, and death.

Breast milk protects against necrotizing enterocolitis.

questions.text: A 12-day old preterm neonate was diagnosed to have necrotizing enterocolitis. She had been switched over from breastmilk to formula feed 5 days after birth as the mother died of COVID-associated complications. Which of the following features will not be seen in the baby?
questions.solution:
Necrotizing enterocolitis can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis (not alkalosis).

Other Signs and Symptoms 

Gastrointestinal  Systemic
Abdominal distention  Lethargy 
Abdominal tenderness Apnea/respiratory distress
Vomiting Temperature instability
Occult/gross blood in stools,  Acidosis- metabolic and/or respiratory
Change in stool pattern/diarrhea Hyponatremia
Abdominal mass Glucose instability
  Poor perfusion/shock
  DIC

questions.text: A 1.9 Kg neonate delivered at 32 weeks has abdominal distention and hematochezia on the 11th day of life. The abdomen x-ray is as shown below. What is the stage of disease according to Modified Bell's Staging Criteria?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray image shows gas accumulation in the submucosa of the bowel wall- pneumatosis intestinalis, a pathognomonic finding of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), seen in stage IIA, according to the Modified Bell Staging Criteria.

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:

Stage   Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs Treatment
IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus NPO, Antibiotic for 3 days 
IB   IA + Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA Same as IA
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus NPO, Antibiotics for 7-10 days 
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness IA+ Metabolic acidosis and thrombocytopenia   IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days 
IIIA Severely ill, bowel intact  IIB + peritonitis with marked tenderness, and abdominal distension  IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascitis  NPO, Antibiotics for 14 days, fluid resuscitation +/- inotropes, ventilator, paracentesis
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumoperitoneum Same as III A, surgery 

Stage I - Suspected NEC
Stage II - Proven NEC
Stage III - Advanced NEC
